text: He sent redemption unto his people: he hath commanded his covenant for ever: holy and reverend is his name.
text_kjv: He sent redemption unto his people: he hath commanded his covenant for ever: holy and reverend is his name.
text_niv: He provided redemption for his people;he ordained his covenant forever—holy and awesome is his name.
text_esv: He sent redemption to his people; he has commanded his covenant forever. Holy and awesome is his name!
text_nlt: He has paid a full ransom for his people.He has guaranteed his covenant with them forever.What a holy, awe-inspiring name he has!
text_msg: He paid the ransom for his people,He ordered his Covenant kept forever.He's so personal and holy, worthy of our respect.
text_nasb: He has sent redemption to His people; He has ordained His covenant forever; Holy and awesome is His name.
context: Psalm 111 is an acrostic psalm, meaning each verse begins with successive letters of the Hebrew alphabet. This literary device aided memorization and emphasized completeness – from Aleph to Tav, God's praise encompasses all. The psalm reflects a time when Israel recognized their redemption from exile or some other national crisis. The repeated emphasis on God's works and righteousness suggests a period of reflection and thanksgiving for divine intervention. The 'fear of the Lord' mentioned throughout wasn't simply terror, but a deep respect and reverence rooted in understanding God's power and holiness. Covenants in the ancient Near East were serious agreements, often sealed with oaths and sacrifices. God’s covenant with Israel, initially established with Abraham and renewed with Moses, formed the bedrock of their relationship. 'Redemption' (Hebrew: *pedut*) often involved paying a price to liberate someone from slavery or debt. In the context of Israel, it often refers to God’s deliverance from Egypt, considered their foundational redemptive act. Kings and rulers throughout the ancient world often had names associated with power and prestige. God's 'name' represents His character, reputation, and all that He is. Declaring it 'holy and reverend' acknowledged His unique and transcendent nature, different from any earthly power.
meaning: This verse encapsulates the heart of God's relationship with His people. 'He sent redemption unto his people' points to God's active intervention in history to deliver His chosen nation. This redemption, initiated in the Exodus, prefigures the ultimate redemption offered through Jesus Christ. It wasn't simply a rescue, but a purposeful act of love and covenant faithfulness. 'He hath commanded his covenant for ever' highlights the enduring nature of God's promise. The covenant is not a fleeting agreement but a binding commitment that transcends time. This promise is rooted in God's unchanging character. The word 'commanded' suggests a decree, an unshakeable law, signifying the permanence of God's promise. 'Holy and reverend is his name' affirms God’s unique otherness and the appropriate response to His character. 'Holy' means set apart, pure, and without blemish, and 'reverend' speaks to the awe and respect that God's holiness demands. God's name is not merely a label but a representation of His very essence, which is infinitely worthy of our veneration. The combination of redemption, covenant, and reverence illustrates a complete picture of God's relationship: He acts to save, He binds Himself in promise, and He demands our worship. The verse serves as a powerful reminder of God's unwavering commitment and our corresponding responsibility to honor His holiness.
application: Psalm 111:9 offers profound applications for modern believers. Firstly, it calls us to reflect on God's redemptive work in our own lives. Have we recognized and appreciated the 'redemption' He offers from sin and despair through Jesus Christ? We must actively remember and celebrate God's saving grace. Secondly, it challenges us to live in accordance with God's covenant. This means understanding and obeying His commands, striving to live a life that reflects His character. The 'covenant' implies a reciprocal relationship. God has fulfilled His part; are we fulfilling ours? This involves studying scripture, praying for guidance, and submitting to the Holy Spirit's leading. Thirdly, it urges us to cultivate a sense of 'holy and reverent' fear of the Lord. This isn't about being terrified of God, but about approaching Him with humility, respect, and a deep awareness of His power and holiness. It means acknowledging that He is God, and we are not. Practically, this translates into careful consideration of our words and actions, seeking to honor Him in all we do. Furthermore, the verse encourages us to share the good news of God's redemption with others. Just as God acted to redeem His people in the past, He continues to offer redemption today. We are called to be witnesses of His grace, sharing the message of hope and salvation with those who are lost and searching. Finally, let this verse fuel our worship. Remembering God’s redeeming acts and permanent covenant should compel us to express our gratitude and adoration in songs, prayers, and acts of service. Make reverence a tangible part of your daily life, consciously seeking to honor God in your thoughts, words, and actions.
prayer: Holy and Almighty God, we thank You for sending redemption to Your people, a redemption that extends to us through Jesus Christ. Thank You for Your everlasting covenant, a promise of faithfulness that never fails. We acknowledge that Your name is holy and reverend, worthy of all honor and praise. Forgive us for the times we have taken Your grace for granted and failed to live up to the covenant You have established. Fill us with a spirit of reverence and awe, that we may approach You with humility and respect. Help us to live lives that reflect Your holiness and to share the good news of Your redemption with others. In Jesus' name, we pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: In the Old Testament, 'He sent redemption' primarily refers to God's deliverance of Israel from slavery in Egypt. This foundational event shaped their identity and demonstrated God's power and commitment to His chosen people, solidifying the covenant relationship and prefiguring future acts of salvation.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: What is the significance of 'He sent redemption unto his people' in the context of the Old Testament?

faqs.answer: While the original covenant was made with Israel, Christians believe that through Jesus Christ, we are grafted into that covenant. We are beneficiaries of God's promises and are called to live in obedience to His commands, demonstrating our faithfulness to the New Covenant established in Christ's blood.
faqs.question: Q2: How does the idea of 'covenant' relate to our lives as Christians today?

faqs.answer: Having a 'reverend' fear of the Lord isn't about cowering in terror, but about acknowledging God's supreme authority and holiness. It manifests as respect, awe, and a desire to please Him in all aspects of life, influencing our choices and priorities.
faqs.question: Q3: What does it mean to have a 'reverend' fear of the Lord in modern society?

faqs.answer: Cultivating understanding requires intentionality. Spend time in prayer and Bible study, meditate on God's attributes, and actively seek to live a life that reflects His character. Surround yourself with godly influences and be mindful of the choices you make each day.
faqs.question: Q4: How can we cultivate a deeper understanding of God's holiness in our daily lives?

faqs.answer: Psalm 111:9 anticipates the ultimate redemption found in Jesus. The Old Testament redemptions were temporary and physical. Jesus' sacrifice provides complete and eternal salvation from sin, fulfilling the promise of a lasting covenant and demonstrating God's unwavering love.
